instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1425: What is A1425? A1425 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Early 2013, Late 2012 with EMC 2672, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3190, 820-3462..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Problem
threads.message:
Hello guys

I have this Macbook Pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which doens't have image/backlight. Below are some measurments


<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> = 3.38v
PPBUS = 12.53V


<TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>
1 = 0V
2 = 0V
3 = 12.43
4 = 12.53
5 = 0V
6 = 0V


DIODE MODE READINGS PIN 3/4 LCD CONNECTOR 0.484v

REPLACE THE IC WITH A KNOW GOOD ONE STILL NO BACKLIGHT

<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> = 5.15V
<SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCA</SIGNAL> = 5.15V


<RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> = 12K
<RESISTOR>R7732</RESISTOR> = 150K

<RESISTOR>R7753</RESISTOR> = 1.6K
<RESISTOR>R7752</RESISTOR> = 1.6K


Know Working Display (From <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ) tested and same results

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Problem
threads.message:
"doens't have image/backlight"
No reason to expect backlight, if no image confirmed.

Do you get external video, USB activity, or chime at least???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Problem
threads.message:
Yes I do have external video through HDMI
I do have chime
I do have USB Activity

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Problem
threads.message:
So the board boots.
But, as I said, backlight appears AFTER internal image.

Check for voltage at pins 5, 9, 28 of J8300; in the first few seconds, when hear the chime.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Problem
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Problem
threads.message:
"pin 9 = 1.01V"
It should be 2.5V aprox and <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> reaches 3V.
Test with compatible LCD assembly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Problem
threads.message: So. I tested with a known working display from an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, My model is an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>. It's compatible right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Problem
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Problem
threads.message:
Got it.
According to those measurements do you think is it BAD display? Or still could be a logic board problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Problem
threads.message:
You should test with good LCD.
Just in case, check <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> level.
5V remains always at pins 28-30 of J8300?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Problem
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Problem
threads.message: Because the LCD itself doesn't send the correct signal to PCH.
